title: Tracking issue for std::num::NonZero* types

labels.name: T-lang
labels.description: Relevant to the language team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

labels.name: T-libs-api
labels.description: Relevant to the library API team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

labels.name: B-RFC-implemented
labels.description: Approved by a merged RFC and implemented.

labels.name: C-tracking-issue
labels.description: Category: A tracking issue for an RFC or an unstable feature.

labels.name: disposition-merge
labels.description: This issue / PR is in PFCP or FCP with a disposition to merge it.

labels.name: finished-final-comment-period
labels.description: The final comment period is finished for this PR / Issue.

body:
This is a tracking issue for the RFC "Add std::num::NonZeroU32 and friends, deprecate core::nonzero" (rust-lang/rfcs#2307).

**Steps:**

- [x] Implement the RFC: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/48265
- [x] Adjust documentation ([see instructions on forge][doc-guide])
- [x] Stabilization PR ([see instructions on forge][stabilization-guide]) https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/50808

[stabilization-guide]: https://forge.rust-lang.org/stabilization-guide.html
[doc-guide]: https://forge.rust-lang.org/stabilization-guide.html#updating-documentation

**Unresolved questions:**

- [x] Should the signed types be included?
- [x] Decide on naming -- `NonZeroU32` or `PositiveU32`? Should the `U` be dropped?
- [ ] Should the memory layout of e.g. Option<NonZeroU32> be a language guarantee?
- [ ] Settle issues wrt. const generics before stabilization.
      -- We should either end up with a generic type or with a clear explanation of why a generic type can't work or doesn't work well.
